summary: Animation.Create() returns null for .lottie files because .lottie is a ZIP archive (dotLottie format), not raw Lottie JSON

stepsToReproduce: Observe that the returned Animation is null

versionAnalysis.relevanceReason: This is not a version-specific issue. The Skottie API has never supported dotLottie ZIP format — it only accepts raw Lottie JSON.

analysis.summary: The reporter is passing a .lottie file (dotLottie format) to Animation.Create(), which expects raw Lottie JSON. The .lottie format is a ZIP archive containing one or more Lottie JSON animations plus a manifest. Skia's Skottie module (skottie::Animation::Make) only parses JSON, so passing ZIP binary data causes it to return null. This is expected behavior — the API doesn't support the dotLottie container format.
analysis.rationale: Classified as question rather than bug because the API is working as designed — Skottie parses Lottie JSON, and the .lottie (dotLottie) container format is a different specification entirely. The reporter's confusion is understandable since both formats use 'lottie' in the name, and LottieFiles defaults to .lottie downloads. The area is SkiaSharp (Skottie sub-module). No severity assigned since this is not broken behavior.

keySignals.interpretation: .lottie files are ZIP archives (dotLottie format), not JSON — Skottie can't parse ZIP as JSON.
LottieFiles now defaults to dotLottie (.lottie) downloads rather than raw JSON (.json). This is a common source of confusion.

keySignals.text: No exception is thrown, so it fails silently
keySignals.interpretation: Factory-null-on-failure is by design in SkiaSharp — Animation.Create returns null when parsing fails. This matches the C++ Skottie behavior.

codeInvestigation.finding: Animation.Create(string path) reads the file into SKData, strips BOM preamble, then passes raw bytes to skottie_animation_make_from_data(). No format detection or ZIP handling.
skottie_animation_make_from_data calls skottie::Animation::Make(data, length) which expects JSON text. ZIP binary data will fail JSON parsing and return nullptr.
Upstream Skia Skottie only exposes Make(data, length), Make(stream), and MakeFromFile(path) — all expect Lottie JSON. No dotLottie format support exists in upstream Skia.

workarounds: Extract the Lottie JSON from the .lottie ZIP archive before passing it to Animation.Create(). The .lottie format is a ZIP containing animations/*.json files.
Download the Lottie JSON format directly from LottieFiles instead of the .lottie format.
nextQuestions: Should SkiaSharp add built-in dotLottie extraction as a convenience, or is this out of scope?

resolution.hypothesis: The .lottie file is a ZIP archive (dotLottie format) containing Lottie JSON. Skottie only parses raw JSON. Extracting the JSON from the ZIP resolves the issue.

proposals.title: Extract JSON from .lottie ZIP
proposals.description: Use System.IO.Compression to extract the Lottie JSON from the dotLottie ZIP archive before passing it to Animation.Create().

proposals.title: Download Lottie JSON instead
proposals.description: On LottieFiles, download the .json format instead of .lottie. The JSON format is directly supported by Skottie without any extraction needed.

resolution.recommendedReason: Most robust solution — works regardless of where the .lottie file comes from. The alternative (downloading JSON) only works if you control the download source.

actionability.reason: The API is working as designed. The .lottie format is not Lottie JSON. A clear workaround exists.

actions.description: Reclassify as question — this is a format confusion, not a bug
Explain .lottie vs Lottie JSON format difference and provide extraction workaround
Close as answered — format confusion, not a bug
Cross-reference #2166 (Skottie BOM loading issue — similar silent null return pattern)
